Hyndburn Borough Council's Regeneration & Housing department spent 12.9 times its monthly average in March — the worst year-end spending spike of any department across the three East Lancashire councils we analysed. In cash terms, that represents £3.7 million above the department's normal monthly spending.

What Is the Year-End Spending Surge?

Every council's financial year runs from April to March. Departments that haven't spent their full budget by March face a choice: return the money to reserves, or spend it quickly before the year ends. Too often, the answer is to spend — a practice known as "use it or lose it" budgeting.

How Hyndburn Compares

Council Worst Department March Spike Above Normal
HyndburnRegeneration & Housing12.9x£3,700,000
BurnleyVarious departments1.7x—
PendleFinancial Services2.7x£1,700,000

At 12.9x, Hyndburn's March spike is nearly five times worse than Pendle's and over seven times worse than Burnley's. This is not a marginal difference — it suggests a fundamentally different approach to budget management.

Why This Matters for Taxpayers

When departments rush to spend £3.7 million in a single month above their normal rate, several problems arise:

  • Reduced scrutiny: Large volumes of spending processed quickly receive less oversight
  • Poor value for money: Urgent purchases are less likely to be competitively tendered
  • Unnecessary spending: If the money wasn't needed for 11 months, was it truly needed in month 12?
  • Budget gaming: Departments that underspend get their budgets cut the following year — so there's a perverse incentive to spend everything

The Regeneration & Housing Question

Regeneration and housing projects often involve large capital expenditures that can legitimately spike in particular months. However, a 12.9x spike specifically in March — rather than any other month — strongly suggests budget-clearing rather than project timing. If this were driven by project milestones, we would expect to see similar spikes in other months too.

What Good Practice Looks Like

Well-managed councils address year-end surges by:

  1. Allowing genuine budget carry-forward for planned projects
  2. Rewarding departments that return unused funds
  3. Requiring additional approval for March spending above a threshold
  4. Publicly reporting year-end spending patterns

All figures derived from publicly available Hyndburn Borough Council spending data. Monthly analysis based on payment dates in published transparency returns.
